description: Borrowed from French (dialectal) beige, from Old French bege (“color of undyed wool or cotton”), from an Alpine language (compare Franco-Provençal bézho, Romansch besch (“dull grey”)), from Vulgar Latin *bysseus (“cottony grey”) (compare French bis, Catalan bis, Italian bigio), from Late Latin byssus (“cotton”), from Ancient Greek βύσσος (bússos, “cotton homespun”), from Semitic (compare Hebrew/Aramaic בוץ‎ (būṣ)). Doublet of bice.

adjectives.description: beige (comparative beiger or more beige, superlative beigest or most beige)

entries.meaning: Having a slightly yellowish gray colour, as that of unbleached wool.
(informal, originally US) Comfortably dull and unadventurous, in a way that suggests middle-class suburbia.
A slightly yellowish gray colour, as that of unbleached wool.
Debeige; a kind of woollen or mixed dress goods.
